transcription.text: >> Hello, everyone. My name is Loy Liu and I'm a co-founder of
Kiber network. Today I'm super excited to be here to give you an update about what
Kiber has been doing, especially in connecting decentralized liquidity for decentralized
finance. Before we go to the details, let's define what is liquidity. I think a lot of
us have heard about liquidity, but not many of us understand what exactly that term means.
So liquidity really represents the degree in which an asset can be sold quickly in the
market without impacting the price. For fiat currency, USD and shipping, they are super
liquid. For asset like Bitcoin and Ether, they are also very liquid. But for many of
the years, they are not as liquid. When it comes to liquidity, there are two main parties.
The liquidity techers are people who buy and sell the asset. They are also the liquidity
providers or people who actually make the offer a further to buy and sell. They work
closely together every time. The main incentive for the market makers is that they are going
to get the profit from the trading, but they also have the reach of holding the inventory
and sometimes the market moves against the direction.
What is decentralized liquidity? There is literally no definition of this term on the
internet. This is really our first attempt. Decentralized liquidity in our definition
is the liquidity that is available in the decentralized ecosystem. There are two important
properties of decentralized liquidity. First of all, there has to be a trustless relationship
between the techers and the providers. That means when they do the trade, there is no
need for trust. There is no middleman sitting in the middle to settle the trade. All the
parameters, including rates, amounts and all these things have to be transparent and verifiable
so that people can detect everything and verify everything before they enter the trade.
Most importantly, it has to be utilizable by decentralized application or smart contract
on public blockchains. This is the current state of all the decentralized liquidity in
the ecosystem. We have several players like Uniswap, Kyber, Reserve, Oasis, from Maker,
Banko and Dash Act from NOSIS as well. The main problem is that all of them are working
in silo. If a dev wants to take liquidity from all of these players, they are able to
have such different integrations. It is going to take a lot of time. It is even really
hardly to find enough liquidity because they don't have enough time and gas to talk to
everyone. This is where Kyber comes in. We are building a decentralized liquidity protocol
that connects all the on-chain liquidity sources, be it Uniswap, Kyber, Reserve, Banko, Oasis
and the main goal is to create one single liquidity pool for all the decentralized application
and wallets and websites to take the best rate available in the market. Basically, they
just talk to Kyber and Kyber will justify the best rate available for them and return
it to the dev. This is one example of how an on-chain index fund can use Kyber. For example,
here, they want to send the eater and convert this eater into an index that has 30% of value,
30% of WBTC and 40% of link. They send the eater in a channel to the index fund and the
index fund will do for what the interruption and the fund to the Kyber contract and will
define the best rate according to each of the asset for the users. In one single-chain
nation, we can return everything to the end users. That will reduce all the friction because
in a non-Kiber chain nation, they may have to do three different chain nations in order
to finish the trade. What are the good properties that we enable? First of all, this Kyber is
just combine all the available liquidity sources and make it single in one single, make it
available in one single interface for any application, any dev to integrate. That results
to make it easy for all of them. Secondly, we have flexible liquidity models so that we
can work with all of the liquidity sources. That's why Kyber is the only one that could
talk to Oasis, that could talk to Uniswap, that could talk to NOSIS and we could even
work with professional market makers. This really allow all the liquidity providers
to use different strategy when it comes to market making on chain. On the other hand,
if you are on Uniswap, there's only automatic market making model and if you subscribe to
some liquidity pool, you have to follow that model. It's the same for Oasis next, for example.
And third, but also the most important property is that Kyber runs everything on chain that
will make it super transparent and verifiable. That means there's no trusted third party
and this is the main reason why we designed Kyber to be fully on chain in the first place.
But later on, when we started working with a few projects, we realized that running fully
on chain make it very easy to connect with others as well. That means there's a great
composability with many other on chain applications. And moving forward, I think this is one of
key concern when Ethereum switch to E2.0, when there are different sharps and running on chain
doesn't mean that you could talk to a different smart contract easily.
This is the start in the last few months. Okay, so we have more than 5,000 monthly unique
addresses that have been using Kyber. The number of liquidity providers that have been working
actively on Kyber is around 30. So value locking, this is the metric that a lot of people are
talking on Twitter, but I don't think it's that important because for Kyber, the value
locking is actually much less than others, but we're processing in terms of the trade
volume, much more than others at the moment. And in the last six months, we are processing
more than 800,000 ether. That is corresponding to around 150 million USD. The number of tokens
that we are supporting is around 70, and we are adding more every month. So in terms of
application integrated, I want to show this figure. So we have more than 65 different
applications, wallets that have been integrating with Kyber to utilize the liquidity pool that
we have, and many of them are here today, like Toto and BZRX. And we can associate a lot
of other DeFi players, like Set Protocol and NuwO and Instad app. In terms of wallets,
I think we are connected to most of the major wallets in the space already, including my
Toto wallet, ARM2K and Ben was here, and Ng and Kyber's wallet. And it's totally open
and permissionless to integrate with Kyber, use the scale to developer.kiber.net work to
see the API. And you can just integrate with Kyber in a couple of hours. I just want to
share a couple of like, you know, spot-line integration that have been using Kyber so
that you can understand, you know, what they use Kyber for, right? The first one is the
in-house end users' decentralized chains, we call it Kyber swap. And the main advantage
is that it optimizes for the user-friendliness, right? We have many features that make it
super easy for the end users to start doing decentralized trading. Some of them are non-custodial
limit orders that allow them to create limit orders even when there's no custodial involved,
but also like price alert. And we also have iOS and Android mobile apps so that the users
can just do it on the phone. And this is the Grow to Kyber swap in terms of straight volume.
This is just like part of the Kyber volume because we have like many other partners that
introduced volume to Kyber as well. But we could see that, you know, from February to
June to July when the market was, you know, booming, we saw a lot of, you know, chain
chain and volume from Kyber swap. But in the last couple of months when it's crude,
we see a doubt chain. But in the last six months, we, on Kyber swap, we have around like
10,000 new users and a lot of them coming from all the end users' marketing that Kyber
swap targeted at conference, at events. And one of the activities that Kyber swap team
did is that they just, you know, distribute the end user gift card with preloaded eater
so that the users can just start using the eaterium blockchain without, you know, the
concern of like acquiring eater or, you know, understanding what's gas and things like that.
Another one is set protocol. And basically what they do is they allow people to manage
the asset in a different strategy. And one simple strategy is that they can just buy
in some index, right? Like, you know, there's a set of basket of asset and the users can
just send eater and set up, users help them buy a basket of asset, including, you know,
it could be like, you know, eat, die or WVDC and you know, right? And set, use Kyber in
background when the users, you know, do that conversion and everything is fully on-chain.
The users can also see all the channels on eater scan or any explorer, right? Another
one that is super interesting is Nuo. They allow people to, you know, borrow and land
crypto, trustlessly. So they basically, you know, if you have eater and you want to borrow
die, right? Users collateralize your eat. And when the price of eat, you know, goes down,
which is unfortunate. Nuo was just liquidate the users' position on Kyber and everything
is done via the smart contract. And the users can also verify the activities. So in case
it's dispute, they can verify it, they can check it and it can be used as a proof. Right?
So that is on the technical side. Let's see how we are doing on the reserve side or on
the liquidity provider side, right? So here's the list of like top 10 liquidity providers
on Kyber. So Kyber, we have our own reserve as well. But at the same time, we also work

makers like their guys in the third position. They don't want to share their identity.
Yeah. And we have different models for people to contribute their liquidity, including like,
you know, Fed price reserve. This is mainly used by the professional market maker. We
also have something similar to Uniswap that we call Automated Price Reserve. And of course
there's the bridge to Uniswap and Oasis as well. And the top share tokens are stable coins
of course, you know, DAI, USDC, and Ether and WBTC and USDT as well. There are a few other
liquid ERC 20 tokens like Maker, Omisego and KMC and Link and BAT as well. So one of
the initiatives that Kyber has been actively working on is, you know, crotchen, right? Like
our goal is to bring more and more asset from different blockchain like BitCoI and EOS and
other blockchain to Ethereum so that the users on Ethereum can trade them, can use them in
a trustless and freely manner. So the first initiative that we launched together with
many other partners, I think six or seven months ago was WBTC. And the idea was very simple,
right? With this, you know, allow people to create a representative of BitCoI on Ethereum,
which is in a form of ERC 20 tokens. And the main question is, you know, who will castorly
the BitCoI for the users? For simplicity, which is not ideal, but, you know, it's very
simple and very easy to understand. With this, use BitCo as a custody. So the users deposit
Bitcoin, they will get, you know, the corresponding amount of ERC 20 WBTC on Ethereum. And if they
want to redeem it, this is Bernadouken and they will get back to BitCoI on BitCoI blockchain.
This is a very widely supported initiative by all the project in the ecosystem. And, you know,
feel free to integrate WBTC in your project, in your DeFi project. Now, it's just like,
you know, adding any other ERC 20 token. Another one that we started not too long ago was the
bridge between EOS and Ethereum. Basically, this is, you know, having, and this is going
to be a trustless bridge. And the idea here is that, like, we could, we essentially build
the like client of EOS on Ethereum and the like client of Ethereum on EOS. And we just allow
people to, you know, verify the transition of one blockchain on another, you know, trustless
manner. The detail of this, you can, you can search a Waterloo bridge, you know, EOS to
Ethereum. You will find the blog post that our developer released a couple of months ago.
And you find all the technical details. Yeah, so final thought. I hope that I have convinced
you that decentralized liquidity is important for DeFi and, you know, they are still scattered.
And we are doing our best in connecting all the liquidity sources on Ethereum. There's
still a lot to do, especially in the cross chain space. We need to have a better mechanism
to, you know, to bring WDC on Ethereum. But, you know, WDC and TBDC as well. And Waterloo,
a good start. We can improve from there. And, yeah, we look forward to work with everyone
on this. And thank you. Is there any Q&A? Oh, okay, sure. Have two minutes. Thank you
so much for your talk. I have two questions. Our first one is about your index fund. I

on-chain transaction of everything. However, are you guys going to solve this issue in

So, I think for the first question, it was just like, you know, out of nowhere. Is this
like, for example, is this for example? Oh, okay. Right. And for the second one, I think

them don't update the price instantly because this cannot. Once you send the transaction
to update the price, you have to wait for like, you know, 15 or 20 seconds. So they have
like to have that in the pricing model to, to, to, yeah. But I think currently the rate
for stablecoins are quite good and they are quite competitive. I think it's as competitive
as centralized in this. I think one thing that is different in Kiber price is that that's
the final price that the user will get. There's no fees after that. So it's the post fee price,
right? But the price on centralized in this, for example, they are like pre-feeced price.
So that's the price you get and then, you know, that's the amount you get before the
fees. So after the centralized in this, the deduct the fees, you may get, you know, less,
less. Yeah. Okay. Thanks.
Hey. Thanks for your talk. So Kiber and Uniswap are becoming the de facto price fees in the
DeFi space. One thing I'm concerned about and would like to understand what you're doing
is things like flash crashes. So if I want to lend some amount, I'm concerned that, you
know, due to thin order books, my, you know, position might get liquidated. What are your
thoughts on that and what do you want to do to prevent these things? Thank you.
I think, for example, on, I think that's a good question. I think, for example, on Kiber,
if you wanted to trade a very large amount, you won't be able to, because we just revert
the transaction. But on Uniswap, because the model, they allow you to scale to, I think,
infinitely, right? If you wanted to sell like 1,800, they could also allow you to do that.
But the price is very bad, because there's no, there's not enough liquid, inventory there.
So on Kiber, we just decided to revert the transaction if there's not enough liquidity.
And I think the only way to address that is to work with more professional market makers
to bring them on chain and to, to help them, you know, provide more liquidity for the DeFi
ecosystem. Okay. If there's no other question, I'm going to be around, so feel free to ask
me.
Thank you.
